text: Active inference offers a unified theory of perception, learning, and decision-making at computational and neural levels of description.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In this article, we address the worry that active inference may be in tension with the belief-desire-intention model within folk psychology because it does not include terms for desires or other cognitive constructs at the mathematical level of description.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: To resolve this concern, we first provide a brief review of the historical progression from predictive coding to active inference, enabling us to distinguish between active inference formulations of motor control
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: MAI, which need not have desires under folk psychology, and active inference formulations of decision processes, DAI, which do have desires within folk psychology.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We then show that despite a superficial tension, when viewed at the mathematical level of description, the active inference formalism contains terms that are readily identifiable as encoding both the objects of desire and the strength of desire at the psychological level of description.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We demonstrate this with simple simulations of an active inference agent motivated to leave a dark room for different reasons.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Despite their consistency, we further show how active inference may increase the granularity of folk psychological descriptions by highlighting distinctions between drives to seek information versus reward.
speaker: SPEAKER_00
